accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research; materials must be requested at least 24 hours in advance of intended use.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: Property rights reside with the repository. Literary rights reside with the creators of the documents or their heirs. To obtain permission to publish or reproduce, please contact the Public Services Librarian of the Dept. of Special Collections.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Purchased, 2004: accession 2004-283. Gift of the Matter family, 2005: accession 2005-114 (Series nine, 300 photographic prints.)

bioghist.head: Biography / Administrative History
bioghist.p: Born in the resort village of Engelberg, Switzerland, Herbert Matter is best known for his international contributions in photography, photomontage, and graphic design work. Matter was also a filmmaker, exhibition designer, and professor. He photographed a wide range of subjects in art, advertising, and fashion. His constant experimenting lead to ongoing refinements in composition, typography, and a variety of printing techniques.
Matter initially studied painting at the Ëcole des Beaux-Arts in Geneva and then at the Académie Moderne in Paris as a student of Fernand Léger, and Amédée Ozenfant.

He came to the United States in 1936 and began work as a freelance photographer for Harper's Bazaar and Vogue magazines and the Museum of Modern Art in New York, and created displays for the Swiss and Corning Glass Pavilions for the 1939 World's Fair.

Over the course of his career Matter worked with Charles Eames, did photography, photomontage, and covers for Arts and Architecture magazine, and served as the design and advertising consultant for Knoll creating the company's award winning graphics, layout, and photography.

He also directed, filmed, and edited Works of Calder in 1950 for the Museum of Modern Art, the first color film to show Alexander Calder's sculptures. While maintaining countless assignments, he introduced the first photography classes offered at Yale University where he taught until 1976.

Matter's most personal artistic endeavor was his extensive photography of the work of sculpture Alberto Giacometti. These photographs from the 1960s and 1970s were published in his book Alberto Giacometti. Matter worked on the book up to the time of his death; it was published posthumously in 1987.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The collection represents the photography and graphic design career of Herbert Matter, his commercial and personal work. This includes original artwork (collages, sketches), photographs (predominately black and white prints, contact prints, working prints), manuscripts, process materials (paste-ups, proof sheets), memorabilia, negatives, transparencies, slides, 16mm motion picture film, printed material, and working equipment. There is considerable correspondence with particularly noteworthy letters from Gregory Ain, John Cage, John Entenza, Walter Gropius, Gyorgy Kepes, Isamu Noguchi, Irving Penn, and Brett Weston among others. The core of the collection is contained in over 100 boxes of graphic art material. In addition, there are over 60 boxes containing photographs, negatives, and transparencies of his commercial and non-commercial photographic work.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Matter collection is arranged in nine Series, with Subseries and Subsubseries augmenting the organizational structure.

scopecontent.p: This series provides details related to Matter's professional life such as his CV (Curriculum vitae), publications featuring his work, awards and certificates, documents including passports, IDs, and material related to exhibitions of Matter's photography and graphic design. Prints and negatives of Matter and his family are in this series along with notes, and written ideas about photography.

scopecontent.p: Photo of Wilhelm and Elaine de Kooning is stamped "Sidney Janis Gallery" on reverse side along with handwritten notes of their names. Two photos of Edward Durrell Stone in the Arts Center, University of Arkansas are stamped "The Property of Magazine of Building" dated 1951, Sept. on reverse side along with handwritten notes of their names and locations. Photo of group including Wallace Harrison, Oscar Nitschke, Harmon Goldstone, Max Abramovitz, and George Dudley are stamped "Property of the Architectural Forum" along with handwritten notes of their names on reverse side. Photo of Roy Lichtenstein and Henry Geldzahler at the St. Phalle opening is stamped "Property of Studio Associates" and photographed by David McCabe along with handwritten notes of their names. Photo of Irving Feldman and Larry Rivers is stamped "Property of Studio Associates" and photographed by David McCabe. Photo of UN architects meeting is dated 1947, Feb. 13 and stamped "Property of the Architectural Forum".

scopecontent.p: This series includes letters and cards to Matter from various clients (such as Knoll Associates), personal contacts and prominent figures such as Isamu Noguchi, Laszlo Moholy-Nagy, Walter Gropius, John Cage, Ray Kaiser (Eames). Includes permission requests for image reproduction, and other publishing related correspondence. A small number of outgoing letters to family and business.

scopecontent.p: Tina Fredericks' letter dated 1955 from Ladies' Home Journal regarding returning of photos. Tina Beebe's letter dated 1983 is of current events and personal correspondence. Response letter dated 1998 from Weston Naef of J. Paul Getty Museum to Mercedes Matter request to display Herbert's work. John Powers' letter dated 1972 is in regards to Jackson Pollock works. Marcel Breuer's memorial card dated 1981. Letter from Marcel Breuer Architect firm dated 1955 regarding Grosse Point Library. Brett Weston's letter dated 1945 regarding bills and house fixture. Willard Morgan of MandM dated 1966 regarding move and returning of clipping. Marvin Kendrick's letter dated 1982 from University of Hartford requesting Herbert as senior visiting critic to Harvard Art School. Irving Penn's personal letters to Herbert dated 1945 and 1946. Personal card from James Lord. Personal letters from John Cage dated 1945 and 1949. James Prestini's letter dated 1956 in regards to availability of Calder Mobiles, leaves, and rippling water on color film. Isaku Yanaihara's letter dated 1971 is in French. Letter from Sidney from Reynal and Hitchcock dated 1944 regarding photo work. Howard Dearstyne's letter dated 1960 is in regards to book proposal on design. Birthday celebration card from Jack Larsen to Martha Kaihatsu dated 1975. Benjamin Baldwin letter dated 1945 requesting photos. Letter from Isamu Noguchi dated 1956 requesting student visa for his brother to the US. Letter from Gyorgy Kepes dated 1951 requesting motion study photographs. Letter from John Entenza dated 1948 regarding job recommendation for Milah Birnie. Letter from Max Bill dated 1955. Congratulation letter from Philip Johnson dated 1955 on Springdale Station. Letter dated 1967 from Massimo Vignelli regarding fee for Knoll furniture shoot. Letter from Harry Weese dated 1959 regarding Cummins project. Letter from Serge Chermayeff dated 1947 regarding job offer to Institute.

scopecontent.p: This series contains material such as oversized prints, posters, objects (scale models), photographic film boxes (empty), 16mm and 35mm film reels and canisters (empty), Matter's 8"x10" format studio camera, contact printer and damaged, though viewable black and white negatives (4"x5" and 8"x10"). The most fragile items in the collection are the predominately black and white glass plate negatives (mostly 4"x5" and some 8"x10"). The glass plates are among Matter's earliest work and includes several images of his photography from Paris, ca. 1928-1932. Also notable are the original (4"x5") glass plates for his studies with "electrostatic discharge emulsion."

scopecontent.p: This series contains approximately half of the Matter collection. It includes both commercial photograph and graphic design work. Completed projects and production materials such as prints, cut and paste, and layout work involved in the development of commercial work. Clients include Knoll Associates (furniture), various museums, New Haven Railroad, Boston-Maine Railroad, Florida National Bank, Swiss National Tourist Office (Ski Posters), Container Corporation of America, Conde Nast publications, arts and architecture magazine and others in addition to unidentified client work. Negatives, transparencies, published examples of work, source material, and working prints. Material is black and white (prints, negatives, transparencies) and color (transparencies, and a small number of color negatives). Graphic designs (layout, paste up, logotypes, sketches) are mostly color, some black and white. Series includes extensive material related to Knoll Associates (1946 to 1966), and the Museum of Modern Art, New York, the Guggenheim, New York and the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston. Collection includes prints and negatives associated with the publication; Masters of modern art; edited by Alfred H. Barr, Jr. for the Museum of Modern Art (New York, N.Y.). New York, Distributed by Simon and Schuster 1954, and Modern sculpture from the Joseph H. Hirshhorn collection. [Commentary: H.H. Arnason], New York, 1962. Catalog of "Exhibition '62/6, October 3, 1962-January 6, 1963." for the Guggenheim. Additionally, Matter's mural designs for the Seagram building and the Grosse Pointe (Michigan) Library.

scopecontent.p: This series represents Matter's personal and creative photography. The majority of the material in this series relates to Matter's photography of sculptor Alberto Giacometti and his work during the 1960s and 1970s. Contains extensive production materials involved in the publication of Matter's book: Alberto Giacometti; text by Mercedes Matter ; foreword by Louis Finkelstein ; with an introduction by Andrew Forge. New York : Abrams, 1987. Series includes negatives, and prints of Giacometti, abstracts, nudes (Mercedes Matter, Provincetown, MA. 1940), Brazil, Native Americans (New Mexico), East Indian Dancers (Pravina and others), and Alexander Calder. In addition to experimental, and assorted non-commerical works.

scopecontent.p: This series is separated into two groups of black and white: contact prints, and negatives. Although stored separately, each contact print (sheet) is numbered to match a corresponding negative. Format of negatives is black and white, generally 2 1/4". In some instances matches do not exist if either the contact print or negative is missing. Series is comprehensive and is not organized by category, subject matter or date, contains both commercial and non-commercial photography.

scopecontent.p: This series contains uncut strips of black and white negatives, predominately 2 1/4" format. These are vintage negatives representing Matter's early commercial and non commercial work of the late 1930s through the late 1940s. Each strip has between ten to twelve individual images. Several of the negatives contained in this series were not printed, and in many instances the images are not otherwise represented in the collection.

scopecontent.p: This series includes 16mm film (black and white, and a small amount of color footage), 35mm film (a small amount of footage, and separate audio track recorded on 35mm film stock), audio reels (seven inch magnetic reels), sound disc (records), video (helical scan, one VHS) and audio cassettes. Due to format, condition and viewing equipment, the 16mm film, 35mm film, helical scan video are currently non-viewable. The subjects of the media series are predominately East Indian Dance, Harlem black dance, and Alexander Calder (Works of Calder film). Series includes footage of Matter's film project on Coney Island. For Matter's film work on R. Buckminster Fuller see the R. Buckminster Fuller Papers, ca. 1920-1983. Collection number: Special Collections M1090.

Series 9: Photographs Gifted from the Matter Family

scopecontent.p: This series contains 300 vintage black and white photographic prints by Herbert Matter. These prints were selected from the Matter Family's personal collection to broadly represent Herbert Matter photographic career, his commercial and non-commercial work. The prints demonstrate Matter's aesthetic and the various photographic and darkroom techniques he employed. Includes examples of infra-red photography, solarization, electrographic photography, photogram, and studio prints. The prints are organized by subject matter in the following categories: Abstracts; Biographical; Alexander Calder; Fashion; Alberto Giacometti; Knoll Associates; Land and Seascapes; Mercedes Matter; Museums; Personal Photography; Portraits; Commercial.
